gurmukhi: kRoD Bry hir jI mnY Gir qy bwhir jwie ] sMig sKw lY kp sBY Awey sYn bnwie ]140]
transliteration: Krodh Bhare Har(i) Jimanai Ghar(i) Te Baahar(i) Jaae|| San(i) Sakhaa Lai Kap Sabhai Aae Sain Banaae||140||
translation: Krishna, in rage, went out of the house, taking the gopa children and monkeys with him, he formulated an army and then returned.140.

gurmukhi: pwQr kO gih kY krY dIno mtu su Bgwie ] KIr dso ids bih clXo Aau pIno hir Dwie ]141]
transliteration: Paathar Kau Gadh Kai Darai Deeno Mat(u) Su Bhagade|| Kheer Daso Dis Bah(i) Chadyo Au Peeno Har(i) Dhaae||141||
translation: All of them broke the pitchers of milk by pelting stones on them and the milk flowed on all the four sides; Krishna and his companions drank the milk to their fill.141.

gurmukhi: sYn bnwie Blo hir jI jsuDw ds kO iml lUtn lwey ] hwQn mY gih kY sB bwsn kY bl ko chUM Er bgwey ]
transliteration: Sain Banaae Bhalo Har(i) Jijasudhaa Dadh Kau Mil Lootan Laae Haathan Mai Gadh Kai Sabh Baasan Kai Bal Ko Chahoon Or Bagade||
translation: In this way, formulating an army, Krishna began to plunder the milk of Yashoda; catching the vessels in their hands, they began to throw them hither and thither;

gurmukhi: PUt gey vr PYl pirE dD Bwv iehY kib ky mn Awey ] kMs ko mIJ inkwrn kO AgUAw jn Awgm kwn jnwey ]142]
transliteration: Phoot Gad Vah Phail Pario Dadh Bhaav Ihai Kabi Ke Man Aae|| Kans Ko Meejh Nikaaran Kau Agooaa Jan Aagad Kaan Janaae||142||
translation: Seeing the milk and curd spread here and there, this idea has come into the mind of the poet that the spread of milk is a sign in advance of the bursting of the marrow from the cracked skull.142.

gurmukhi: Por dey iqn jo sB bwsn kRoD BrI jsuDw qb DweI ] PwD cVY kip rUKn rUKn gÍwrn gÍwrn sYn BgweI ]
transliteration: Phor Dae Tin Jo Sabh Baasan Krodh Bhari Jasudhaa Tab Dhaaee|| Phaadh Chadai Kap(i) Rookhan Rookhan Rookhan Gvaaran Gvaaran Sain Bhagadee||
translation: When all the vessels were broken by Krishna, then Yashoda ran with rage; the monkeys ascended the trees and the army of gopa children was made to run away by signs by Krishna;

gurmukhi: daurq daur qbY hir jI bsuDw pir AwpnI mwq hrweI ] sXwm khY iPrkY biRj ky piq aUKl so Puin dyih bMDweI ]143]
transliteration: Daurat Daur Tabai Har(i) Jibasudhaa Par(i) Aapanimaat Haraaee|| Sayaam Kahai Phirkai Brij Ke Pati Eekhal So Phoun(i) Deh (i) Bandhaaee||143||
translation: Krishna kept running and his mother was exhausted; the poet Shyam says that when Krishna was caught, he the Lord of Braja was tied with the ukhal (large wooden mortar).143.

gurmukhi: daur ghy hir jI bsuDw jb bwNiD rhI rsIAw nhI mwvY ] kY iekTI biRj kI rsIAw sB jor rhI kCu Qwih n pwvY ]
transliteration: Daur Gade Har(i) Jibasudhaa Jab Baandh(i) Rahiraseeaa Nahimaavai|| Kai Ikathikiraseeaa Sabh Jor Rahikachh(u) Thaah(i) Na Paavai||
translation: When Yashoda ran to catch Krishna and toed him, he began to cry; the mother gathered together the roes of Braja, but Krishna could not be bound down;

gurmukhi: Pyir bMDwie Bey biRj ky piq aUKl so Dir aUpir DwvY ] swD auDwrn ko jumlwrjnu qwih nimq ikDO vh jwvY ]144]
transliteration: Pher(i) Bandhaae Bhae Brij Ke Pat(i) Ookhal So Dhar(i) Oopar(i) Dhaavai|| Saadh Udhaaran Ko Joumlaarjan(u) Taah(i)namit Kidhau Vah Jaavai||144||
translation: Ultimately, he was tied with ukhal and began to roll on the earth; this was being done only for the salvation of Yamlajuna.144.

gurmukhi: GIsiq GIsiq aUKlih kwnH auDwrq swD ] inkit qbY iqn ky gey jwnnhwr AgwD ]145]
transliteration: Gheesat(i) Gheesat(i) Ookhlah(i) Kaahn Udhaarat Saadh|| Nikattee Tabai Tin Ke Gad Jaanan-haar Agaddh||145||
translation: Dragging the ukhal behind him, Krishna began to emancipate the saints, He, the unfathomable Lord went near them.145.
